title: 107_s1686
content: The Act titled "Safe Nursing and Patient Care Act of 2001" is cited as the short title. The Congress recognizes the importance of adequate nurse staffing levels for patient safety and outcomes. Despite evidence supporting this, there are challenges in recruiting and retaining nursing staff, leading to mandatory overtime and fatigue among nurses. In the United States, health care providers use mandatory overtime to staff facilities. Requiring nurses to work extended shifts leads to fatigue, contributing to medical errors and compromising patient safety. Limiting mandatory overtime will ensure public safety, quality care, and nurse retention. SEC. 3. LIMITATIONS ON MANDATORY OVERTIME FOR NURSES. Provider agreements under the Social Security Act are amended to include limitations on mandatory overtime for nurses, prohibiting them from working beyond scheduled shifts or more than 12 hours in a 24-hour period. Provider agreements under the Social Security Act are amended to include limitations on mandatory overtime for nurses, prohibiting them from working beyond scheduled shifts or more than 12 hours in a 24-hour period. Exceptions to this rule apply during declared states of emergency when nurses may be required to work longer hours to provide emergency medical services to the community. During declared states of emergency, nurses may be required to work longer hours to provide emergency medical services to the community. Providers must make efforts to fill staffing needs through alternative means before requiring nurses to work beyond scheduled shifts. Nurses have the right to report violations of these limitations on mandatory overtime. During declared states of emergency, nurses may file complaints against providers who violate limitations on mandatory overtime. The Secretary will investigate complaints and require providers to establish a plan of action to address violations. Nurses can file complaints against providers for violating limitations on mandatory overtime. The Secretary will investigate and require providers to address violations, including establishing a plan of action and potential civil money penalties. Nurses are protected from retaliation for refusing mandatory overtime or reporting violations. Nurses are protected from retaliation for refusing mandatory overtime or reporting violations by reporting to regulatory agencies, initiating investigations, or discussing violations with other employees or healthcare professionals. Nurses are protected from retaliation for refusing mandatory overtime or reporting violations by reporting to regulatory agencies, initiating investigations, or discussing violations with other employees or healthcare professionals. Providers of services are prohibited from filing complaints against nurses who refuse to work mandatory overtime. Nurses are considered to be acting in good faith if they believe the information reported is true and a violation has occurred or may occur. Providers of services must post a notice specifying nurses' rights, including the ability to file complaints with the Secretary for violations. Additionally, nurse schedules must be regularly posted in a conspicuous manner. Providers of services must post nurse schedules in a conspicuous manner and make them available to nurses upon request. The Secretary may impose a civil money penalty of up to $10,000 for each knowing violation of this provision. The Secretary may impose more severe civil money penalties on providers of services who establish patterns of repeated violations. The names of providers facing penalties will be published on the Department of Health and Human Services website. The Department of Health and Human Services publishes names of providers facing civil money penalties for violations. Penalties for previous ownership will not be disclosed after a year. Nurses can work beyond specified hours if consistent with safe patient care standards. Mandatory overtime is defined as hours worked exceeding specified periods. In this subsection, definitions are provided for terms related to overtime for nurses. Mandatory overtime is defined as hours worked exceeding specified periods, with potential adverse consequences for refusal. Overtime is simply defined as time worked beyond specified periods. A nurse is defined as a registered nurse or a licensed practical nurse. The curr_chunk provides definitions for terms related to healthcare providers and declared states of emergency. It includes definitions for providers of services such as hospitals, clinics, and home health agencies, as well as the term "declared state of emergency." The curr_chunk defines terms related to healthcare providers and declared states of emergency, including providers like hospitals, clinics, and home health agencies. It also defines "declared state of emergency" as an officially designated emergency declared by the Federal Government or appropriate state/local agency, excluding emergencies from labor disputes or understaffing. The effective date for these amendments is 1 year after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 4. REPORTS. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will conduct a study to establish safe working hour standards for nurses providing healthcare. The study will consider various factors and recommendations for maximum work hours will be submitted to Congress within 2 years. Additionally, a study on mandatory overtime in federally operated medical facilities will be conducted. The Secretary will submit a report to Congress with recommendations for maximum work hours standards for nurses. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget will conduct a study on overtime practices in federally operated medical facilities. The term "federally operated medical facilities" includes hospitals, clinics, and home health care facilities run by government departments. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget will report to Congress within 6 months with recommendations on nurse overtime policies in these facilities.
